questions.prompt: A fair six-sided die is rolled. What is the probability of rolling a number greater than 4?
questions.explanation: Numbers greater than 4 are {5, 6}. There are 2 favorable outcomes out of 6 possible, so P = 2/6 = 1/3.

questions.prompt: Two coins are flipped. What is the probability of getting exactly one head?
questions.explanation: Sample space: {HH, HT, TH, TT}. Exactly one head: {HT, TH}. P = 2/4 = 1/2.

questions.prompt: The sum of all probabilities in a sample space must equal 1.
questions.explanation: This is one of the fundamental axioms of probability (Kolmogorov axioms).

questions.prompt: Which of the following is NOT a valid probability value?
questions.explanation: Probabilities must be between 0 and 1 inclusive. 1.2 > 1, so it cannot be a valid probability.

questions.prompt: The set of all possible outcomes of a random experiment is called the ______ space.
questions.explanation: The sample space is the fundamental concept in probability theory representing all possible outcomes.

questions.prompt: If P(A) = 0.4, P(B) = 0.5, and P(A ∩ B) = 0.2, what is P(A|B)?
If events A and B are independent, then P(A ∩ B) = P(A) × P(B).
questions.explanation: This is the definition of independence: two events are independent if and only if P(A ∩ B) = P(A) × P(B).

questions.prompt: If P(A) = 0.6 and P(B|A) = 0.3, what is P(A ∩ B)?
questions.explanation: Using the definition of conditional probability: P(A ∩ B) = P(B|A) × P(A) = 0.3 × 0.6 = 0.18.

questions.prompt: Two events A and B are mutually exclusive with P(A) = 0.3 and P(B) = 0.4. Are they independent?
questions.explanation: Mutually exclusive events (except those with probability 0) cannot be independent. If P(A ∩ B) = 0 but P(A) × P(B) = 0.12 ≠ 0, they are not independent.

questions.prompt: The probability of event A given that event B has occurred is denoted P(A|B) and is called ______ probability.
questions.explanation: Conditional probability measures the probability of an event given that another event has occurred.

questions.prompt: How many different 3-letter arrangements can be made from the letters A, B, C, D, E (without repetition)?
How many ways can you choose 2 items from a set of 5 items (order doesn't matter)?

A disease affects 1% of the population. A test is 95% accurate for sick people and 90% accurate for healthy people. If someone tests positive, approximately what is the probability they have the disease?
questions.explanation: Using Bayes' theorem: P(Disease|Positive) = P(Positive|Disease)×P(Disease) / P(Positive). P(Positive) = 0.95×0.01 + 0.10×0.99 = 0.1085. So P(Disease|Positive) = 0.0095/0.1085 ≈ 0.088 or about 9%.

questions.prompt: The number of permutations of n distinct objects is n!.
questions.explanation: The factorial n! counts all possible orderings of n distinct objects.

questions.prompt: Bayes' theorem allows us to update our beliefs about a hypothesis based on new ______.
questions.explanation: Bayes' theorem is fundamental for updating probabilities when new evidence or information becomes available.
